Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Low-Cost, Nickel-Based Metallization Pastes for Solar Cell Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project goes well beyond lowering the metallization costs for silicon photovoltaic (PV) cells. In the PV space, the introduction of nickel based metallization pastes can make solar cell modules cheaper and more sustainable. With global demand for energy expected to increase by approximately 40% from its current level of 17 terawatts (TW) to 24 TW by 2035, PV module production must increase from 35 gigawatts (GW) per year in 2013 to >150 GW per year to satisfy a meaningful portion of this new demand. Silver based metallization pastes used in solar cells currently consume 5% of all annual silver production, making large increases in PV production unsustainable in the long-term. In addition, the fundamental mechanism of protecting base metal particles from oxidation at elevated temperatures has far reach implications that can address problems in the integrated circuits and electromagnetic interference shielding industries.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will commercialize nickel (Ni) based metallization pastes as replacements for silver (Ag) metallization pastes on silicon photovoltaic (PV) cells. Silver (Ag) based metallization pastes are used in over 90% of solar cells being manufactured today. However, the high cost of Ag results in the pastes accounting for roughly 7-10% of the cost of the completed silicon solar cell, making alternatives to Ag highly desirable. The spot price of nickel is fifty times less than Ag and orders of magnitude more abundant. Previous attempts to use Ni in metallization pastes have failed due to the rapid oxidation of Ni particles in air when fired at normal processing temperatures for solar cells. This Phase II project will commercialize a technology that protects the Ni particles in the metallization paste from oxidation while allowing the resulting conductive film to remain solderable for connecting cells together in a module. During this project the nickel-based metallization paste will be scaled up and tested on pilot lines of large silicon PV cell makers and show equivalent performance, yield and reliability when compared to standard Ag metallization pastes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the NSF SBIR program, PLANT PV developed a novel metal powder that, when formulated into a metallization paste, can enable the majority of the solar cells that are currently being manufactured to increase power output while reducing cost. Importantly, the company's technology does not require solar cell makers to use any new equipment or processing steps, which removes any barriers for adoption by the solar cell industry. Over the course of the NSF Phase II project, the company successfully demonstrated, on multiple tests in different facilities, the performance advantage of its technology over incumbent technologies. This was achieved while significantly lowering the use of silver, which is a key cost driver for solar cell manufacturers.

In parallel, the company successfully scale up production of its proprietary metal powders to very large volumes and demonstrated the capabilities to do so at low cost. This has set the stage for rapid scale-up of the final product, which is a low-silver content metallization paste for the rear tabbing layer of silicon solar cells.

Once in production, the company's technology will boost the power output of solar cells, which has the potential to generate an additional 300MW of power output annually, which can power ~50,000 homes. This has a signifcant impact on greenhouse gas emissions.

In addition, the company has trained six undergraduate researchers, four of whom were part of the Research Experience for Undergraduates program operated by the NSF. These researchers not only learned hands-on skills in the lab but also learned to structure research efforts, execute on those efforts, analyze data, create a well-structured presentation and present their findings to a broader group of scientists. Since their experiences with our company, all of these researchers have expressed interest in both pursuing a higher degree in the sciences and starting businesses to develop innovative technologies for the broader public.

Finally, PLANT PV has disseminated many of its findings to the broader industry through discussions and testing programs. This has ignited interest in pursuing this technology for different applications. We anticipate our technology entering into new solar module architectures as well as low temperature conductive film applications.
